body:
To update -- I also tried to build from source with CUDA EP (specified my cuda and cudnn paths explicitly) and succeeded to build. But after installing the built wheel it still says the same error: `CUDA_PATH is set but CUDA wasn't able to be loaded.`

Could anyone please guide me on which step I did wrongly? Thanks a lot

So far, I couldn't reproduce it.

Could you install pytorch to double check whether it is an issue of CUDA installation ?
`python -c "import torch; torch.cuda.is_available()"`

And it'd better provide the output message of 
`nvidia-smi`
and
`nvcc --version`

Hi I tried all three just now (installed cuda 11.6 and the onnxruntime-gpu wheel was complied locally with my current cuda and cudnn):
```
Python 3.8.10 (tags/v3.8.10:3d8993a, May  3 2021, 11:48:03) [MSC v.1928 64 bit (AMD64)] on win32
Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.
>>> import torch
>>> torch.cuda.is_available()
True
>>> exit()
```

```

Since the onnxruntime with cuda ep could be compiled on my local machine, it seems that my local cuda and cudnn works fine with onnxruntime? Felt like it might be some of the dynamic libraries (dll files on windows) couldn't be loaded successfully. 

I later checked with dependency walker but it shows that all dependencies could be located. And also tried to run the test script with windbg -- no error throws for dll loading but the python terminal still says ` LoadLibrary failed with error 126`. I've been stuck on this for days and would really need some help. Thanks a lot

From your `PATH`, the nvcc version should be 11.4, but it shows 11.6
run `where nvcc` you might find C:\Program Files\NVIDIA GPU Computing Toolkit\CUDA\v11.6\bin at the first place.

what's the output `set | findstr CUDA`

Sorry the first post is outdated. I tried to uninstall cuda 11.4, installed cuda 11.6 and compiled ort + cuda ep with the current cuda 11.6 earlier today. 

The path now is with cuda 11.6 and cuda 11.4 is not there anymore
```
C:\Users\user\projects\test\env_py38\Scripts;C:\Windows\System32;C:\Program Files\NVIDIA GPU Computing Toolkit\dll_x64;C:\Program Files\NVIDIA GPU Computing Toolkit\dll_x64;C:\Program Files\NVIDIA GPU Computing Toolkit\dll_x64;C:\Program Files\NVIDIA GPU Computing Toolkit\CUDA\v11.6\bin;C:\Program Files\NVIDIA GPU Computing Toolkit\dll_x64;C:\Program Files (x86)\Vim\vim82;C:\Users\user\AppData\Local\Microsoft\WindowsApps;C:\Users\user\AppData\Local\Programs\Microsoft VS Code\bin;
```

`set | findstr CUDA` only prompts me to  set variables, not sure if this is expected.
```
PS C:\Users\user> set | findstr CUDA

cmdlet Set-Variable at command pipeline position 1
Supply values for the following parameters:
Name[0]:
```

`where nvcc` outputs the cuda 11.6 path:
```
C:\Users\user>where nvcc
C:\Program Files\NVIDIA GPU Computing Toolkit\CUDA\v11.6\bin\nvcc.exe
```

> `set | findstr CUDA` only prompts me to set variables, not sure if this is expected.
> 
> ```
> PS C:\Users\user> set | findstr CUDA
> 
> cmdlet Set-Variable at command pipeline position 1
> Supply values for the following parameters:
> Name[0]:
> ```

`set | findstr CUDA` is  a batch command. it runs in normal windows command window.

Why there're multiple `C:\Program Files\NVIDIA GPU Computing Toolkit\dll_x64` in PATH? what's in it?

Since you've already installed the CUDA11.6, could you try re-installing the offical onnxruntime-gpu 1.13.1 in a clean virtual environment. 
And check the output of  
`pip show onnxruntime-gpu`
`python -c "import onnxruntime as ort; print(ort.get_device())"`
`python -c "import onnxruntime as ort; print(ort.__version__)"`

Thanks! here's the output of `set | findstr CUDA`
```
C:\Users\user\projects\test>set | findstr CUDA
Path=%PATH%;C:\Program Files\NVIDIA GPU Computing Toolkit\dll_x64;C:\Program Files\NVIDIA GPU Computing Toolkit\CUDA\v11.6\bin;C:\Program Files\NVIDIA GPU Computing Toolkit\dll_x64;C:\Program Files (x86)\Vim\vim82;C:\Users\user\AppData\Local\Microsoft\WindowsApps;C:\Users\user\AppData\Local\Programs\Microsoft VS Code\bin;C:\WINDOWS\system32;
```
I left the zlib dll in the `dll_x64` folder and added it in the path as instructed in [cuda install guide](https://docs.nvidia.com/deeplearning/cudnn/install-guide/index.html#install-zlib-windows), sorry for the confusion.

And for the outputs of the newly install onnxruntime-gpu 1.13.1 in a clean venv:
```
(clean_env) PS C:\Users\user\projects\test> pip show onnxruntime-gpu
Name: onnxruntime-gpu
Version: 1.13.1
Summary: ONNX Runtime is a runtime accelerator for Machine Learning models
Home-page: https://onnxruntime.ai
Author: Microsoft Corporation
Author-email: onnxruntime@microsoft.com
License: MIT License
Location: c:\users\user\projects\test\clean_env\lib\site-packages
Requires: coloredlogs, flatbuffers, numpy, packaging, protobuf, sympy
Required-by:
(clean_env) PS C:\Users\user\projects\test> python -c "import onnxruntime as ort; print(ort.get_device())"
GPU
(clean_env) PS C:\Users\user\projects\test> python -c "import onnxruntime as ort; print(ort.__version__)"
1.13.1
```

Sadly the problem persists with the new ort-gpu 1.13.1 as well..
```
['TensorrtExecutionProvider', 'CUDAExecutionProvider', 'CPUExecutionProvider']
2022-11-10 00:46:19.8506006 [E:onnxruntime:Default, provider_bridge_ort.cc:1266 onnxruntime::TryGetProviderInfo_CUDA] D:\a\_work\1\s\onnxruntime\core\session\provider_bridge_ort.cc:1069 onnxruntime::ProviderLibrary::Get [ONNXRuntimeError] : 1 : FAIL : LoadLibrary failed with error 126 "" when trying to load "C:\Users\user\projects\test\clean_env\lib\site-packages\onnxruntime\capi\onnxruntime_providers_cuda.dll"

2022-11-10 00:46:19.8601278 [W:onnxruntime:Default, onnxruntime_pybind_state.cc:578 onnxruntime::python::CreateExecutionProviderInstance] Failed to create CUDAExecutionProvider. Please reference https://onnxruntime.ai/docs/reference/execution-providers/CUDA-ExecutionProvider.html#requirements to ensure all dependencies are met.
```

It looks you didn't add the cuDNN directory into the PATH
```
Add the NVIDIA cuDNN bin directory path to the PATH variable:
Variable Name: PATH 
Value to Add: C:\Program Files\NVIDIA\CUDNN\v8.x\bin
```
https://docs.nvidia.com/deeplearning/cudnn/install-guide/index.html#installwindows

Where did you put your cudnn file?
if you copy the cudnn files into the same directory as cuda files , you don't need to specify additional ENV.
```
C:\Program Files\NVIDIA GPU Computing Toolkit\CUDA\v{version}\include\x64
C:\Program Files\NVIDIA GPU Computing Toolkit\CUDA\v{version}\h
```
If you copied them into another directory, such as  
`C:\Program Files\NVIDIA\CUDNN\v8.x\includ`e and` C:\Program Files\NVIDIA\CUDNN\v8.x\lib`
you could try adding ENV CUDNN_HOME=C:\Program Files\NVIDIA\CUDNN\v8.x

The cudnn related files in bin/lib/include were copied into cuda corresponding folders before. And my local ort-gpu was able to be compiled with these cuda and cudnn versions.

To double check 
- I have another standalone folder with cudnn v8.2.2.26
- I added `CUDA_HOME=C:\Program Files\NVIDIA GPU Computing Toolkit\CUDA\v11.6` and `CUDNN_HOME=C:\Program Files\NVIDIA GPU Computing Toolkit\CUDNN\v8.2.2.26` variables to env, still the same error
- Also added `;C:\Program Files\NVIDIA GPU Computing Toolkit\CUDNN\v8.2.2.26\bin`  to my `PATH`, same error as well.

I'm really confused, if environment paths have all been set correctly, are there any other reasons why the ort binary files are able to be compiled with cuda and cudnn but they couldn't be loaded during inference? And how may I investigate deeper on the causes. Thanks!

Since it's completed successfully, could you debug with 
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/16190118/201256383-120664d6-035e-4f52-a2a9-238982b547de.png)

Apologies that I'm new to windows programming and VS, please bear with me on this silly question -- how may I debug on this? I tried to run the local debugger (as in the screenshot) and it seems just to compile the library again. I used to compile through command line with 
```
./build.bat --build_wheel --config RelWithDebInfo --skip_tests --build_shared_lib --parallel --use_cuda --cudnn_home 'C:\\Program Files\\NVIDIA GPU Computing Toolkit\\CUDA\\v11.6' --cuda_home 'C:\\Program Files\\NVIDIA GPU Computing Toolkit\\CUDA\\v11.6' --cmake_generator "Visual Studio 17 2022" --cuda_version 11.6
```

In the VS, the arguments are not being specified, is this only compiling the cpu version? Do I need to compile with cuda (possibly with command line again), then use VS to debug on the compiled output? Thanks a lot

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/8852730/201278194-fb868625-4cf4-48ba-add4-773910db72db.png)

The build seems somehow failed and it prompted to use the previous build (I would assume it's the one built with cuda, not sure now though). And here are the outputs. It looks like the $CUDAToolKitDir is empty. Do I need to specify it manually or maybe it's some  internal variable onnxruntime sets and uses?

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/8852730/201280260-597fbfca-110d-4367-bbb2-35a1eba00c0a.png)

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/16190118/201297603-c6593a27-895e-429f-af6d-7483108bf2db.png)
update `Debug` to `RelWithDebInfo`

And set(right click) onnxruntime_test_all to `Setup As a Startup Project`

> ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/16190118/201297603-c6593a27-895e-429f-af6d-7483108bf2db.png) update `Debug` to `RelWithDebInfo`
> 
> And set(right click) onnxruntime_test_all to `Setup As a Startup Project`

Hello, I encounter the same problem, I solved it by install cuDNN. It seemed that I installed CUDA only. I download the cuDNN zip, and copy the include, lib, bin folder to the same folder in CUDA path, problem solved.

For anyone who might find this helpful -- it turned out to be some mess in the setting of my system path. Using conda to create an isolated environment with clean installed cuda and cudnn solved this.

> For anyone who might find this helpful -- it turned out to be some mess in the setting of my system path. Using conda to create an isolated environment with clean installed cuda and cudnn solved this.

I want to know how to solve this problem in the end, I am also troubled by the same problem as you before, thank you for your answer, it is very helpful.

I resolved the same issue lately. My solution is
pip install torch==1.x.y+cu11x (The version won't be important.)
Use "import torch" before "import onnxruntime"

> I resolved the same issue lately. My solution is pip install torch==1.x.y+cu11x (The version won't be important.) Use "import torch" before "import onnxruntime"

It worked for me tks
i  solved this problem by this video  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2TcnIzJ1RQs

Also solved this issue recently by changing to specific CUDA version mentioned in the chart here: [https://onnxruntime.ai/docs/execution-providers/CUDA-ExecutionProvider.html](https://onnxruntime.ai/docs/execution-providers/CUDA-ExecutionProvider.html). I thought the CUDA 11.x family was backwards compatible but only the specific driver version mentioned worked for me.
